Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content:
in `~/.komodo/VRSC` add a VRSC.conf file like:
`rpcuser=SomeUser
rpcpassword=SomePass
rpcport=27486
server=1
txindex=1
rpcworkqueue=256
rpcallowip=127.0.0.1`

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <O_User> @englal  ðŸ˜ƒ good point. But well, depends if the value of the project is in the price value of the coin or not... One could value the project and not have to follow the price necessarily. If he's still got coins he would've (might've) sold, he's going to have to be a part of the community longer than he may have planned if he was "lucky" enough to get the coins straight off the bat. 

If you are holding coins that you can't touch for 24 months, you probably are going to pay less attention to the price however. It would only be pertinent in the weeks leading up to the unlocking to watch the price. 

I'm here for the project first and foremost, if I get rich at the same time it's a bonus... others, I don't know, but many may see a coin as a coin and an investment opportunity and nothing more. They judge the content and the intent of the coin as part of the valuation of the investment. I really like the dynamic of locked coins though, it's very interesting trying to understand what it means to be involved in a crypto project but not actually have the coin in hand.

As for selling, it's inevitable that over time people will sell some of their holdings. For cash flow, diversification, dealing with debts etc. This way we're just not going to have that leakage in the same way. Although with more users we would hope some would sell to expand the partipant base of the project

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <englal> @O_User Great points all around. I didn't phrase it clearly, but I meant pay attention to the project, rather than pay attention to the price. ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @cryptopat You can get the privkey from the wallet you want to move from then import the privkey ONE AT A TIME using the import private key function.
DO NOT try to import multiple private keys.  That does NOT work and sort of screws things up a bit by locking out those privkeys without fully importing them.   
It is very easy, but you just need to know where to get the privkeys and avoid the mistake of trying to import a list of them instead of one at a time.  I cannot stress that enough - ONE AT A TIME.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <O_User> @TexWiller said the opposite I believe, at some point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <O_User> memory could be wrong

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <O_User> I've done one at a time mostly so far, had some problems with wallet scan and it not showing up, but they arrived safe and sound once I imported again and did a wallet scan

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <O_User> I think I did also do a couple with dumpwallet and there was no option to wallet rescan on import so same issue that I couldn't see that they had imported, so didn't like it, but it worked

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jimboscott> @O_User I tried to import a set of private keys by following the instructions on the Agama wallet.  They did not import and, when I then tried to import them one at a time - they would not import singly either.  I believe the wallet partially imported somehow during the attempt at multiple key importation and that led the wallet to ignore the single key import after that.  I had to restore my wallet.dat to a previous state  before I could get them to import as singles.  @miketout confirmed that the multiple import should be avoided.  Pretty sure that's who it was.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <O_User> ok no worries, thanks for clarifying
